meta.title: Cell biology: Overview of cell structure

content:
Introduction

Cellular architecture has many important correlations to human health and disease.  This article outlines the structure and functional organization of the cell, with details covered in separate articles.

Cell organization



Human cells are highly compartmentalized, with each structure performing specific functions.  The nucleus contains and regulates access to the genetic code.  The cytoplasm surrounds the nucleus and serves as the site of translation, metabolism, and signaling.  Within the cytoplasm, membrane-bound organelles have specific roles in biosynthesis, degradation, and energy production.

Nucleus



The nucleus is the command center of the cell, containing the nuclear genome and regulating gene expression.  It consists of the following:



  • The nuclear envelope, the outer membrane of the nucleus, is a double-membrane structure perforated by small pores that regulate transport between the nuclear matrix and the cytoplasm (eg, of RNAs, nuclear proteins, and transcription factors).  Its outer membrane is contiguous with the rough endoplasmic reticulum, which has ribosomes attaches to its cytoplasmic surface.
  • The nucleosome contains DNA wrapped around histone octamers (chromatin).  Chromatin, which helps modulate gene transcription (DNA to RNA), exists as unpacked euchromatin (transcriptionally active) and densely packed heterochromatin (transcriptionally inactive).
  • The nucleolus is a dense intranuclear region where ribosomal RNA (rRNA) is transcribed and ribosomal subunits are assembled.
  • Nucleoplasm, the internal fluid matrix of the nucleus, provides the medium for diffusion and contains:
    • Nucleotides (building blocks of DNA and RNA), S-phase enzymes (eg, DNA polymerase, helicase, topoisomerase), DNA repair enzymes, and DNA-associated proteins (eg, transcription factors).
    • Pre-mRNA processing enzymes (eg, spliceosome proteins, poly-A polymerase, 5′ methyl capping transferases).
    • Cell cycle checkpoint proteins (eg, cyclins, cyclin-dependent kinases) that participate in cell cycle regulation.

Cytoplasm



Whereas gene expression and genome maintenance occur in the nucleus, most biosynthetic reactions, protein translation, and intracellular signaling occur in the cytoplasm, both in the cytosol and in membrane-bound organelles.  The cytoplasm contains:



  • The cytosol, which is the aqueous intracellular solution where many biochemical reactions (eg, glycolysis, nucleotide synthesis), RNA processing and degradation, and signal transduction (eg, second messengers) take place.
  • Free ribosomes, which are complexes of rRNA and protein that synthesize soluble cytosolic proteins.
  • Cytosolic inclusions, which are normal temporary storage compartments for nutrients (eg, glycogen, lipid droplets) or secretory granules for preformed bioactive mediators (eg, histamine granules, neurotransmitter vesicles).

Subcellular organelles



Organelles are membrane-bound or protein-complex compartments with specialized roles.  They include:



  • Secretory pathway organelles (endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus) for synthesis, posttranslational modification, and trafficking of membrane-bound or secreted proteins to their correct location.
  • Disposal pathway organelles (proteasomes, lysosomes, endosomes, peroxisomes) for degradation of proteins, damaged organelles, cellular debris, and ingested pathogens.
  • Mitochondria, which contain their own genomes (mitochondrial DNA) and ribosomes, for oxidative phosphorylation, fatty acid beta-oxidation, and apoptosis regulation via cytochrome c release.

Cytoskeleton



The cytoskeleton is an array of filamentous proteins that determine cell shape, motility, and intracellular transport.  It includes:



  • Microfilaments (actin) for cell motility and shape shifting.
  • Intermediate filaments (various proteins) for structural reinforcement.
  • Microtubules (tubulin) for intracellular transport, cell division (eg, mitotic spindle), and cilia.

Cell surface



The cell surface consists of the plasma membrane and associated structures that mediate barrier function, molecular transport, and cell surface signaling.  It includes the:



  • Glycocalyx, which is an outer carbohydrate-rich coat that protects cells from chemical or mechanical injuries (eg, extracellular enzymes, shear stress), mediates adhesion, and regulates innate immune recognition (eg, ABO antigens).
  • Plasma membrane, which is a phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins such as receptors, ion channels, transporters, and junctional proteins (eg, occludins, cadherins, connexins).
  • Membrane microdomains, which are tiny regions for receptor clustering, endocytosis, or focused signaling compartmentalization.  They include:
    • Lipid rafts (eg, Fc epsilon receptor–IgE [FCεR-IgE] clustering in mast cells).
    • Clathrin-coated pits (eg, internalization of transferrin).
    • Caveolae (eg, insulin receptor and GLUT4 translocation).

Integrated systems



Most cell processes span multiple locations.  Some examples are listed.

Metabolic pathways



Major biochemical pathways have dual cytosolic and mitochondrial phases:



  • Amino acid catabolism involves transamination in the cytosol (eg, alanine transaminase) and deamination in mitochondria (eg, glutamate dehydrogenase) to release free ammonia.
  • The urea cycle involves mitochondrial enzymes (eg, ornithine transcarbamylase) that initiate ammonia detoxification and cytosolic enzymes (eg, arginase) that complete the conversion of ammonia to urea for excretion.
  • Gluconeogenesis begins in mitochondria (eg, pyruvate carboxylase) and continues in cytosol (eg, phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase) to generate free glucose.
  • Heme synthesis involves mitochondrial (eg, aminolevulinic acid synthase) and cytosolic steps.
  • Pyrimidine synthesis occurs primarily in the cytosol but requires a key mitochondrial enzyme (dihydroorotate dehydrogenase).
  • Beta-oxidation involves fatty acyl-CoA activation in the cytosol, transport into mitochondria via the carnitine shuttle, and beta-oxidation within the mitochondrial matrix.  Separately, very-long-chain fatty acids are initially shortened in peroxisomes before entering mitochondria.


Metabolic processes confined to the cytosol include glycolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway.  Red blood cells (RBCs), which lack nuclei and mitochondria, use these pathways to generate ATP and NADPH (which regenerates reduced glutathione for antioxidant defense), respectively.  Lack of mitochondrial metabolism makes RBCs uniquely susceptible to pyruvate kinase deficiency (hemolysis due to ATP depletion) and glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase deficiency (hemolysis due to hemoglobin oxidation).

Corticosteroid hormones



Corticosteroid hormone synthesis (eg, cholesterol to pregnenolone) begins in the mitochondria and then proceeds largely in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (eg, additional modifications to produce cortisol, aldosterone, testosterone, estrogen, and others).  Corticosteroid hormone signaling begins with cytosolic receptors, followed by nuclear translocation to regulate gene transcription.

Apoptosis



Apoptosis begins in the mitochondria (eg, cytochrome c release), amplifies in the cytoplasm (eg, caspase cascade), and culminates in the nucleus (eg, DNA fragmentation, chromatin condensation.

Gene expression



Gene expression begins with transcription and pre-mRNA processing in the nucleus, followed by translation of mRNA by cytoplasmic ribosomes (for soluble cytosolic proteins) or rough endoplasmic reticulum–bound ribosomes (for secreted or membrane-bound proteins)

Cell cycle



Cyclins are synthesized in the cytoplasm and translocate to the nucleus at key transitions in the cell cycle to activate cyclin-dependent kinases.  For instance, cyclin B accumulates in the cytoplasm during the G2 phase and enters the nucleus only at the M phase (mitosis) to trigger nuclear envelope breakdown.

Summary



The nucleus is the central regulatory hub for gene expression and cell cycle control, which are coordinated via chromatin states, the nucleolus (ribosomal RNA), and nuclear-cytoplasmic transport.  The cytoplasm contains free ribosomes dedicated to synthesizing soluble cytosolic proteins, whereas specialized inclusions provide temporary storage for nutrients or bioactive compounds.  Membrane-bound organelles are organized into distinct systems:  Secretory organelles (endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus) process and traffic secreted or membrane-bound proteins, disposal organelles (lysosomes, proteasomes, and peroxisomes) degrade macromolecules and damaged structures, and mitochondria drive energy production and regulate apoptosis.  The cytoskeleton maintains cell shape, facilitates intracellular transport, and enables mitotic division.  At the cell surface, the glycocalyx and plasma membrane microdomains enable receptor signaling.  Many essential cellular processes span multiple compartments.
